artefact.alternative_title: Notification of marketing of food for particular nutritional uses (England)
artefact.overview: You must notify the Department of Health (DH) when you first put a product on the UK market if you manufacture or import food that is sold for particular nutritional uses.
artefact.licence_short_description: Notify the Department of Health (DH) when you first put a product on the UK market if you manufacture or import food that is sold for particular nutritional uses.
artefact.licence_overview:
If you manufacture or import food that is sold for particular nutritional uses, sometimes known as 'parnuts' or 'PNU' food, you must notify the [Department of Health (DH)](http://www.dh.gov.uk/en/index.htm "Department of Health (DH)"){:rel="external"} when you first put a product on the UK market.

##How to notify

Notification is made by providing the DH with a copy of the product label and completing a form.

If you place the food on the market in another European Union member state, you must make similar notifications to the relevant body in that member state before the food goes on the market.

You must also provide any scientific data or information required by the DH in order to show the food fulfils nutritional requirements for those they are aimed at.

A parnuts food is a food which, due to its special make-up or manufacturing process, is easily identifiable from food intended for normal consumption, and is sold so that it indicates its suitability for its claimed nutritional use.

These are usually foods marketed to:

- people with digestive or metabolic issues (eg coeliacs)
- people whose physiological condition means that they would get special benefit from eating certain substances in the food
- infants or young children in good health

The DH may suspend or restrict trade in a product that they find does not comply with requirements or endangers public health. A declaration from the DH in restricting trade may detail conditions on trading. If so, any food marketed must comply with the conditions.

##Fines and penalties

%If you market foods without notifying the DH trade in food whilst a suspension or restriction is in place or fail to comply with any trade conditions you may commit an offence and be fined up to £5,000.%

*[DH]: Department of Health
